Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Hierarchical Functioning of River Macrosystems in Temperate Steppes - From Continental to Hydrogeomorphic Patch Scales
Award.AbstractNarration:
The need to understand and manage ecosystems at larger regional to continental scale macrosystem levels is becoming increasingly crucial with global climate changes and impacts of exotic plants and animals in freshwater rivers and lakes. Macrosystem management requires an understanding of how different levels of spatial complexity (within a stream reach to entire river valley scales) and biotic organization (populations to ecosystems) affect the functioning of rivers and lakes. The present study will provide this information for 18 rivers spread equally between the two largest temperate steppe biomes of the world: the North American Great Plains and the Euro-Asian Steppes (including those in Mongolia). This project will provide research experiences for under-represented participants (particularly rural and Native American students), stimulate STEM program recruitment in largely under-represented (EPSCoR) states, support some faculty and students at primarily undergraduate institutions, and contribute to scientific education at both graduate and undergraduate institutions in two countries.

These rivers flow through 3 major types of ecoregions within these temperate steppe biomes: mountain steppe shrublands, short-to-tall grasslands, and semi-arid shrublands. Scientists and students from the USA and Mongolia will sample the structure and functioning of these 18 rivers in a variety of hydrogeomorphic areas, such as constricted, meandering, braided, and anastomosing channel sections. Despite their similarity in biome and ecoregional types, the river macrosystems of the Great Plains and the Mongolian steppes vary substantially in fauna, flora, and community through ecosystem functioning. These variations result from differences in climatic patterns, the degree of riverine landscape modification (e.g., by dams, levees, and riparian modification), and the naturalness of the resident fauna. For example, most rivers in the USA contain some dams and many exotic fauna have been introduced, while the vast majority of Mongolian rivers contain no dams and their aquatic fauna is almost exclusively natural and different from those in the USA. Moreover, the Central Asian subcontinental area of Mongolia has one of the strongest warming signals on earth, with air temperatures rising three times faster than the overall northern hemisphere average. Consequently, riverine macrosystems in the USA can help predict changes to Mongolian rivers as a result of pending dam construction and possible species introductions to some rivers, while knowledge of responses of Mongolian macrosystems to more rapid climatic changes can help predict future effects in U.S. rivers. Therefore, this project's goals are to: (a) compare and contrast hierarchical scaling relationships and effects of system drivers and cross-scale interactions on rivers in similar biomes and ecoregions of the two continents; and (b) evaluate effects of climatic changes and anthropogenic disturbance to these river macrosystems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a comparative analysis of river ecosystems in Mongolia and the Western U.S.  One of the critical factors structuring river ecosystems is their thermal and hydrologic regimes - i.e., the annual patterns of change in water temperature and water levels and flow.  For some rivers, removal of fish (often top predators in the food chain) from fishing can also be an important structuring force in the food web.  Our focus within the broader project was on the combined impacts of climate change and fishing on fish populations in Mongolian rivers.  Because fishing involves human behavior, we studied both the people (fishermen) and the fish populations of these rivers.

Our research identified one important stabilizing mechanism for fish populations experiencing the effects of climate change and fishing.  Although climate change has raised air and water temperatures in Northern Mongolia, one of the most salient aspects of climate change in this region is a shift in summer precipitation from gentle rains to intense thunderstorms.  Rain from these thunderstorms quickly runs off the surrounding landscape and into rivers bringing with it a great deal of sediment.  While this sediment can have many negative impacts on fish populations, our research shows that it likely reduces mortality from fishing as catch rates decline sharply with turbidity.  For heavily fished populations, the net effect of increased turbidity from summer thunderstorms on survival may be positive.

We also found a potentially destabilizing factor for Mongolian fish populations involving the feedback between fish abundance and fishing pressure.  This work focused on an iconic and ecologically important top predator in Northern Mongolian rivers, the taimen (Hucho taimen).  This fish grows to a maximum recorded size of over 200 lbs, although individuals over 40 lbs are rare.  These large salmonid fish attract fishermen from all over the world.  Our research found that a stabilizing mechanism present in many fisheries is absent in this one.  Often, as fish populations decline, the resulting decline in catch rates and fish size make for a less attractive fishing opportunity.  As a result, fishermen switch to other fishing opportunities, allowing the population some relief and an opportunity for recovery.  In the Mongolian taimen fishery, however, we found that most foreign anglers think of taimen fishing as a trip of a lifetime - one that they are unlikely to repeat regardless of the fishing quality and one that is attractive for many reasons other than catching fish (e.g., the scenery and the adventure).  Thus, fishing pressure for taimen is driven less by the size or abundance of fish, but by the available pool of wealthy foreign anglers and the marketing abilities of taimen fishing lodges.  As taimen populations increasingly suffer the impacts of climate change, they are unlikely to find relief from reduced fishing pressure.

The broader impacts of our research stem from a more nuanced understanding of how climate change can impact fish populations and fisheries as well as from the training of students.  Our results are an important reminder that climate change can act on river ecosystems through both direct physical impacts (warming and hydrological change) but also through changing humans' use of riverine ecosystem services such as fish or irrigation water.  Northern Mongolia, which has experienced some of the most rapid climate warming in the world over the past 40-50 years, provides a research environment in which we can study changes that are predicted to occur in much of the U.S. over the coming decades.

This project provided a unique dissertation research opportunity for a PhD student at Rutgers in the Ecology and Evolution graduate program, Abigail Golden.  The research results described above represent two chapters of her dissertation.  This five-year grant provided the stability of knowing that field data collections in Mongolia would be supported over a longer period and this stability encouraged Abigail to fully invest in basing her dissertation research there by, for example, learning the Mongolian language in an immersive summer program.
